questions.prompt: On a V-I graph (voltage on y-axis, current on x-axis), what does the slope represent?
questions.explanation: Slope = ΔV/ΔI = R (Ohm's law: V = IR). If current is on y-axis and voltage on x-axis (I-V graph), slope would be conductance G = 1/R.

questions.prompt: A component's V-I curve passes through the origin and is a straight line. This component is:
questions.explanation: Linear V-I through origin means V = IR with constant R — the definition of an ohmic resistor. Diodes have exponential curves; batteries have non-zero intercepts; capacitors don't have simple V-I relationships.

questions.prompt: During V-I measurement, the ammeter should be connected:
questions.explanation: Ammeters measure current FLOWING THROUGH them, so they must be in series. Connecting in parallel creates a short circuit through the ammeter's near-zero resistance.

questions.prompt: V-I data: (2V, 1mA), (4V, 2mA), (6V, 3mA). What is the resistance?
questions.explanation: R = V/I = 2V/1mA = 2kΩ, or 4V/2mA = 2kΩ, or 6V/3mA = 2kΩ. All points give the same R, confirming ohmic behavior.

questions.prompt: A student plots V-I data and gets R² = 0.65. This suggests:
options: Poor linear fit — component may be non-ohmic
R² cannot be calculated for V-I data
questions.correctAnswer: Poor linear fit — component may be non-ohmic
questions.explanation: R² = 0.65 means only 65% of voltage variation is explained by a linear current relationship. Ohmic resistors typically show R² > 0.99. Low R² indicates non-linear behavior or excessive measurement noise.

questions.prompt: Which formula gives the least squares estimate of resistance from V-I data?
questions.explanation: Least squares minimizes Σ(V - RI)². Setting derivative to zero gives R̂ = ΣVI / ΣI². This optimally weights the data points and minimizes total squared error.

questions.prompt: A 2.2kΩ resistor is tested with V = 0 to 10V. The V-I curve should span current range:
questions.explanation: At V = 10V: I = V/R = 10V / 2.2kΩ = 4.55mA. At V = 0: I = 0. So current spans 0 to ~4.5mA.

questions.prompt: Two V-I curves are plotted. Curve A has slope 5V/mA, Curve B has slope 2V/mA. Which has higher resistance?
questions.explanation: Slope = ΔV/ΔI = R. Curve A: R = 5V/mA = 5000Ω = 5kΩ. Curve B: R = 2V/mA = 2kΩ. Higher slope = higher resistance.

questions.prompt: A component's V-I curve is exponential (I increases rapidly with V). This component could be:
questions.explanation: Diode current follows I = Is(e^(V/Vt) - 1), which is exponential. Resistors of all types show linear V-I curves under normal operating conditions.

questions.prompt: Loading error in V-I measurement occurs when:
options: The ammeter has too high resistance
questions.explanation: Loading error occurs when the measurement instrument affects the circuit. A voltmeter drawing current reduces voltage across the component. An ammeter with high resistance drops voltage, reducing current. Both distort the true V-I relationship.
